[all packages] [package zeta.format] [class hierarchy] [index]

public abstract class zeta.format.Format

(source file: Format.pizza)
java.lang.Object
   |
   +----zeta.format.Format
The pure class interface. 
public abstract class Format
  implements Serializable
A format represents a structured text which can be pretty-printed for different column-widths. Formats are constructed in a term-like fashion, by composing formats from basic text and given formats. Based on reflection, formats can be automatically generated for arbitrary objects, to visualize object structures for debugging purposes.

The Format class is an abstract class that is inherited by several concrete Format classes which are found in the package zeta.format.impl. Yet, all access to format functionality can be made via the Format class, which provides static methods for constructing formats.

Concepts

If a Format is printed, it uses up a text-rectangle. A text-rectangle is an area of characters in the output stream. It has an indentation, a width of the longest line, a with of the last line, and a height. The text-rectangle visualises as follows: 

  [-indent--|----------width----------]
   .........._________________________ 
  :	   h|			      |
  :	   e.			      .
  :	   i.			      .
  :	   g.			      .
  :	   h|		 _____________|
  :........t|___________|
	    [-lastWidth-]
For every Format, the maximal width and maximal width of the last line, the minimal width (depending on the width of the widest sub-format) and minimal width of the last line and also the minimal height (depending on the number of line-breaks in the Format) are computed by the pretty printer algorithm to determinate how (composed) formats should be grouped. Maximal widths are used to determine wether a Format might still fit fully on the current line, while minimal widths are used in cases where several successive Formats shall be printed 'beside' each other. If a a format doesn't fits on the current line, it is printed on the next line with the given indentation, otherwise the indentation is ignored.

There are several composition operators for formats, which all take an arbitrary number of subformats:
  • beneath(subformats) This operator always puts it subformats beneath each other: 
      ...._______________________.....
  :  |			     |	 :
  :  |			     |	 :
  :  |		   __________|	 :
  :..|____________|______________:
  :    |			 |
  :    |   ______________________|
  :....|__|______................:
  :...|__________|
  • block(subformats) This compound Format is for subformats that should be appended to one another. If the text of one component Format does not fit on the rest of the line (into the given width), a new line is opened before printing that text.

    This is for instance very useful for the printing of the contents of an array. As long as the next item still fits into the current line, it gets printed, if the next item would not fit, then a new line is opened first, where the item then will be printed instead. 
      ....______________.....
  :..|_____|________|	:
  : |	       |	:
  : |	 ______|________:
  :.|___|_____|_____|___|
  :   |		  |	:
  :   |	    ______|.....:
  :...|____|
  • line(subformats) This is a compound Format for subformats that should either be printed into one line (if they all would fit into that line) or beneath each other, otherwise. This behaviour is especially useful for lists of items that are quite complex, so it would not be wise to print several of them into one line for more than one line, since that could lead to confusion for the reader.
  • beside(subformats) This is a compound Format for subformats that should be printed 'beside' each other. This means, that each text is printed beside the end of the last line of the text before it, if it still fits on the line. Otherwise a new line is opened an the format is printed on the next line. 
      ...________________........
  : |		     |	    :
  : |  ....__________|______:
  :.|__:__|		    |
  :    :  |    ...._________|
  :    :..|____:__|	  | :
  :	       :  |    ___|.:
  :............:..|___|
  • append(subformats) This behaves like the beside-operator. However, unlike the beside-operator, which prints the formats beneath each other, if the text would otherwise become too wide, the append-operator prints its components 'beside' each other in every case, so it should be used very carefully.

    The append-behaviour is especially useful for interpunctions that should normally not be printed on the beginning of a new line. Instead the break should be made before the block preceding the item to be appended.

Format
public Format();

empty
public static final Format empty;
A constant holding the empty format.

brk

public static final Format brk;
A constant holding a format which causes a line break.

space

public static final Format space;
A constant holding a space of width 1.

space
public static Format space(int width);
Construct a space of given width. On the beginning of a line, the space will be ignored.

literal

public static Format literal(String s);
Construct an atomic format from a string. The string should not contain any newlines, moreover all spaces within the string will never be ignored.

text

public static Format text(String s,
                          String delimiters);
Construct a format from a string which may contain newlines. The string is broken into lines which are composed by the beneath-operator, each line is furthermore broken into words separated by the given delimiters, which are composed by the block-operator. Each delimiter occurence is replaced by a single space-format.

buildFormat

public static Format buildFormat(Object object);
Build a format for an arbitrary object. If the object implements the Formattable interface, its customized toFormat() method will be used. Otherwise, a generic method based on reflection will take over.

Note that the output of the generic method is not intended for user representation of objects, but rather for debugging purposes. Note further that currently the generic method can only consider public fields of objects.

See also:
toFormat

build

public static <A> Format build(A object);
A generic version of buildFormat(Object), which can be used for Pizza mapping (e.g. aggregate.map(Format.build)). (Pizza only).

buildFormat

public static Format buildFormat(FormatInfo info,
                                 Object object);
Build a format for an arbitrary object, based on the given context information.

See also:
buildFormat, FormatInfo

setIndent

public Format setIndent(int indent);
Set the indentation of this format. By default, the indentation of all created formats is set to 0. Returns this format, which is modified by side-effect. You should only use this method for formats you have created yourself.

See also:
indent

indent

public Format indent(int indent);
Indents this format. Returns a new format which will be indented as specified.

See also:
setIndent

indent

public static Format indent(Format fmt);
Indents the given format statically by 2.

list

public static <A> Format list(Format open,
                              Format next,
                              Format close,
                              (A) -> Format fmt,
                              Aggregate<A> agg);
Make a list of the elements of some aggregate type, with the formatter function for the elements given. (Pizza only.)

list

public static Format list(Format open,
                          Format next,
                          Format close,
                          Aggregate<Object> objects);
Make a list of the elements of a aggreagte of objects. The objects are formatted using the buildFormat method. (Pizza only).

list

public static Format list(Format open,
                          Format next,
                          Format close,
                          Object[] objects);
Make a list of the elements of an array of objects. The objects are formatted using the buildFormat method.

parenth

public static Format parenth(boolean yes,
                             Format fmt);
Put parenthes around the given format if boolean flag is true, otherwise return format.

parenth

public static Pair<Format, int> parenth(Pair<Format, int> p,
                                        int demandedPrio);
Put parenthes around a priorized format iff the demanded priority is larger then the given priority. Returns a priorized format with at least the demanded priority. If parenthes need to be generated, the return priority is Integer.MAX_VALUE. (Pizza only.)

describe

public static Format describe(String message,
                              String[] infoKeys,
                              Format[] infos);
Build a format for `describing' something. The format has the general layout: 
     This is the message.
       InfoKey1      : Info1
       ...
       InfoKeyN      : InfoN

printFormat

public void printFormat(PrintWriter stream,
                        int width);
Prints the given format on the given printer, with the given column with.

Parameters:
stream - the PrintWriter where the Format shall be printed
width - the width the text of the Format shall maximally take on the PrintWriter (if at all possible).
See also:
PrintWriter, printText

toString

public String toString();
Converts a format to a string. A maximal column with of 79 is assumed.

Overrides:
toString in class Object

toString

public String toString(int width);
Converts a format to a string, with the specified maximal column width.

dumpText

public abstract void dumpText(PrintWriter writer);
Dumps a format without any layout calculation to a print writer. Only ``hard'' newlines (induced by the beneath-operator or by explicite breaks) will be considered. This is useful for e.g. code generators which generally construct formats as output, but depending on options need not always to produce user-readable output.

nesting

public int nesting();
For implementation purpose of formats only.

Returns:
the nesting of this Format (default nesting is 0) The nesting of a Format is the number of spaces that are added to the current indentation when printing the Format.

maxWidth

public abstract int maxWidth();
For implementation purpose of formats only.

Returns:
the maximal width the Text of the Format would take if there were no limited width to be considered. The indentation of the Format is ignored.

minWidth

public abstract int minWidth();
For implementation purpose of formats only.

Returns:
the minimal width needed to print out the Format Obviously this is the width of the longest basic Format in compound Formats.

minHeight

public abstract int minHeight();
For implementation purpose of formats only.

Returns:
the minimal height needed to print out the Format Basically, this is one more than the number of newlines the Format contains.

maxLastWidth

public abstract int maxLastWidth();
For implementation purpose of formats only.

Returns:
the maximal width the last line of the Text of the Format could take.

minLastWidth

public abstract int minLastWidth();
For implementation purpose of formats only.

Returns:
the minimal width needed by the last line of the Text of the Format.

printTextBeside

public abstract TextRectangle printTextBeside(int indentation,
                                              FormatStream stream,
                                              int width,
                                              int lastWidth);
For implementation purpose of formats only.

Every one of the concrete Format classes implements its own version of this method so that different output behaviours are achieved.

Parameters:
indentation - the indentation that is to be used for lines of the Format (which is only used at the beginning of new lines)
stream - the FormatStream on which the Format shall be printed
width - the maximal width the printed Text of the Format may take
lastWidth - the maximal width the last line of the Text of the Format may take.
Returns:
a TextRectangle containing actual width, height and lastWidth the printed Text did take.

appendText

public abstract int appendText(int indentation,
                               FormatStream stream);
For implementation purpose of formats only.

Append the Format onto the given stream to the current line after the given indentation. This method is used for Formats that fit into the rest of the line, only. Thus, this has to be assured before calling the method.

Returns:
the width used for printing the format

printTextBeside

public TextRectangle printTextBeside(int indentation,
                                     FormatStream stream,
                                     int width);

printText

public TextRectangle printText(int indentation,
                               FormatStream stream,
                               int width,
                               int lastWidth);
For implementation purpose of formats only.

This method assumes that the Format shall be printed in a new line.

Returns:
the TextRectangle returned reflects only the rectangle taken up by the text to the right of the given indentation.
See also:
printTextBeside
